Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Publisher.place: Titilari, Suco Fuiloro, Lospalos, Lautem District, Timor Leste
Abstract: This book documents 828 sung verses of Vaihoho from cultural collaborators in the Lautem District of Timor Leste.  Señor Valentim explains in the Fataluku language introduction that he was prompted to record Vaihoho (sung poems) because they were not practised or understood by younger generations, and are in danger of being lost.  The sung poems include descriptions of traditional marriage arrangements, and dealing with disagreements between different groups.
Note.content: This book was prepared in collaboration with Mr Michio Takahachi from the Timor Loro Sa'e-Nippon Culture Center (TNCC), who is now deceased.  Many attempts have been made to contact the Nippon Culture Center without success.  Known cultural collaborators were contacted about the project.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Publisher.place: Titilari, Suku Fuiloro, Lospalos, Lautem District, Timor Leste
Abstract: This booklet documents Fataluku language Vaihoho (sung poems) handed down through generations. The sung poems cover various topics including forging good relationships between groups.
Note.content: Cultural collaborators are named, as well as the tribe to which each collaborator belongs.  Señor Valentim is Cailoru, other tribal names are Aca Loho, Latu Loho and Asale.  Individuals in the women's group from Malahara (Lata Malahara i tupurara)  are not named individually.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Extract from a small notebook with handwritten documentation of Vaihoho sung poems from Tutuala tribes.  The language is high Fataluku, used for ceremonial purposes.
Note.content: Depending on the situation, for example the dedication of an 'uma lulik' (sacred house) or traditional marriage negotiations, older Vaihoho practioners may use a high version of Fataluku, which is not well understood by speakers of domestic Fataluku.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Extract from a larger notebook detailing Fataluku Vaihoho sung poems.  Pages _0006_a and _0006_b include Fataluku Vaihoho stanzas on the left, with Tetum explanation of the significance of the stanzas, rather than a direct translation into Tetum.
Note.content: The cultural contributors are named on page 0012.  Benidito Rodrigues is renamed Benedito Marques on page 0013.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Notes collected by Justino Valentim delineating Vaihoho sung poems: friendly partings and saying goodbye before going to home villages.  The language is high, formal Fataluku.
Note.content: Undated loose papers transcribing Fataluku Vaihoho verses.  The cultural contributors are not designated.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract:
Thirteen loose pages previously held in a folder, with Vaihoho from Mr. Manuel Xisto.  The Vaihoho uses metaphoric language to depict romantic relationships, traditional marriage, and the plight of orphans.  Pages _0012 and _0013 deal directly with the Indonesian invasion and occupation.
Halu vaihoho (war song) tell about the tragedy of the conflict and massacres involved when Indonesia occupied Timor Leste. Many people were killed, but some were able to escape by hiding in forest areas.
Note.content:
An example of halu vaihoho can be found at

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mIOwcI85dL8&t=61s
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)|~|Gonsalves, Orlando (Cailoro)
Abstract: Transcriptions of Vaihoho by Senor Valentim recorded in an exercise book.  Senor Gonsalves (deceased) is the knowledge holder.  The languauge is in high Fataluku, which few people now use or understand.  Content of the sung poems is in two parts.  Up to verse 26 are poems for the Cailoru tribal people, detailing local places, traditional names of people and orphan farewells.  From verse 27 the vaihoho are about romantic relations among young girls and young boys.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)|~|da Conceiçāo, Inacio (Nazaratu)
Note.content: Senhor Inacio Conceiçāo is an elder from the sub-village of Ira-Ara in Lospalos.  He is from the Naza Ratu (tribe).
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)|~|da Conceição, Inacio (Nazaratu)
Abstract:
This is the second notebook from Senhor Inacio Da Conceiçāo obtained by Senhor Justino Valentim, documenting vaihoho sung poems (First notebook is jv_vaihoho_0008).   This notebook describes vaihoho from the Pitileti Naza ratu (tribe) from Ira-Ara sub-village in Lospalos.

Most of the Vaihoho are in high Fataluku and include Vaihoho sung at traditional marriage ceremonies, references traditional names and working songs.  Pages _0003, _0004,  _0029 and _0030, use everyday Fataluku and are about the war and Indonesian occupation.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Annotated typed pages of Vaihoho using high Fataluku.  Topics include relationships between different villages, orphan's laments, traditional marriages, ceremonies for traditional sacred house (Uma Lulik).  The additional handwritten verses on the first page use everyday Fataluku and are affectionate goodbyes.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract:
Hand written notebook containing Fataluku Vaihoho sung poems with some translated into Tetum.  The subject of the poems is the beautiful country of Timor Leste.  

Page _0003 English translation of the Tetum (on right hand side):
Lospalos Lospalos
Where is Lospalos
In the good country
With mountains all around
Note.content:
Lospalos is the sub-district of the Lautem District, which is the home district of the Fataluku speaking people of Timor Leste; Lospalos, the town, is also the administrative capital of the Lautem District.
This book also includes an inserted supplementary page of handwritten Vaihoho verses which deal with the natural world.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language|~|Fataluku sung poems|~|Vaihoho|~|Fataluku oral traditions|~|Timor Leste land

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Written in everyday Fataluku these notes discuss firstly, the tribes who are located in the sub-district of Titilari. The second set of notes transcribes a traditional Fataluku song, not a Vaihoho.  The song has been popularised by a contemporary Timor Leste band called Galaxy.
Note.content: The notes are written on the back of cut-up cigarette cartons.

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Hand written notes by Justino Valentim.  The language is high or ritual Fataluku, used mainly by older individuals in formal or ceremony situations.  Younger speakers of Fataluku find the language difficult to understand.  The content is a lament for/by individuals left alone.
Note.content: Field notes written in pencil on lined paper, probably from an exercise book.

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Hand written Fataluku word lists by Justino Valentim.  Pages three to five are lists of Fataluku, Makasae, Makalero and Tetum.  Makasae and Makalero are local languages from Iliomar and Luro respectively.  Pages six to twelve are 'a' and 'b' words from Tetum to Fataluku.
Note.content: The lists are written on a notebook.

Original language title: Draft Fataluku Dictionary by Justino Valentim
Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Draft Fataluku dictionary, researched and prepared by Justino Valentim, listing Fataluku words alphabetically alongside the  meaning of the word in Fataluku.  The draft contains handwritten annotations.  Words beginning with b, d,and g, are not listed; there are lists of words beginning with p, r, s and t, with no word meaning alongside. There are no words beginning with letter Q, V, X and Y in Fataluku.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language

Original language title:
Hakarek Kona ba Timor Loro Sa'e
Fata-lukunu I Disionariu
English translation of title:
Know About Timor Leste
Fataluku Dictionary
Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: In the Introduction, written in Fataluku, Justino Valentim explains that there are many different local languages spoken everyday in the Lautem District.  There are approximately 35,000 people who speak Fataluku, along with Saini ho Naine (approximately 12,000 speakers),and Makalero (approximately 12,000 speakers mostly from Iliomar).  Previously Makuwo language was spoken readily but it is now a lost language.  Mr Valentim hopes that the Fataluku dictionary presented, will help to preserve this local language into the future, and encourage others to continue researching the Fataluku language.
Note.content: The pamphlet is office printed, stapled and tape bound.
Subject.topic: Timor Leste languages|~|Fataluku language

Creator: Valentim, Justino (Cailoru)
Abstract: Alphabetical listing of Bahasa Indonesian words matching to Fataluku meanings.
Note.content: The pamphlet is well-used with water damage
